title: What are the oldest towns in England? - Quora

response.answer_text: You specify England, so that rules out Brodgar in the Orkneys (which may have been more of a religious community rather than a town). Stonehenge is slightly younger at ~5000 BCE. It is hard to imagine something on that scale being constructed without considerable community resources, and that community would have to live in a settlement or settlements. Whether you consder them as ‘towns’ - that’s hard to judge. I bet they didn’t have a mayor and town council. Ceasar mentions defended settlements like Wheathampstead - it had a wall but was it a ‘town wall’? The oldest definitive record is for the Roman settlement of Colchester in 77 CE, but there must have been Iron Age settlements big enough to qualify. Or even pre-Iron Age. And then we come to ‘merry’, and that’s a problem. People can be merry sometimes and miserable the next but given that ale has been brewed since Stone Age times, you could say any town could qualify as merry. Then again, hops were not introduced until the 15th century - perhaps that should be the start date? With the Black Death truly over, business expanding and Chaucer contributing, I’ll put the start date there.

Ain’t no such place as Merry Old England how are things in Rooting Tooting Texas. But in England it’s difficult to know which town or city is oldest many have roots that go back to prehistory so which one is oldest ? Amesbury the town closest to Stonehenge that has evidence of occupation that goes back as far as then. The village of Cheddar although not a town, is home to Cheddar Cheese, Cheddar Gorge and Caves and in one cave England’s oldest complete human Skeleton Cheddar Man That is dated using Carbon 14 isotope ratios to 9000 years ago. When a team from Oxford University took DNA samples from his teeth the decided to match it with that of some local residents. To their surprise they found one Mr Andrew Targett was a direct descendant.
